And then, just a quick housekeeping one for Patrick. Can you just give us a bit more detail on how the accounting works for the intersegment transactions and how it impacts the consolidated model?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Wow, it looks like a 3-way question. All right. We'll work hard on that. So I think on the e-commerce side, I think Google has been using e-commerce for forever, and we're really excited about doing a better job and that I think we want to remove friction when people are buying online or in the real world. We know how people often click on an ad on a mobile device and then may make their purchase on their laptop or they might, in fact, buy it in the store, and we need to really get the conversion data there to the advertiser. So I think we've done work across all those things, across multi-screens, multi devices, from online to offline. We recently launched cross-device measurement in AdWords. And we're also just trying to make it easier for people to buy things in general. We've also rolled out some same-day shipping and local inventory in Search. And like I said, we're just looking to reduce friction, and we're very excited about that.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. Hey, Ben. If you look at the last 15 year of history like you talked about, a lot of the gains of online advertising have actually come at the expense of what we would call performance advertising. Anytime you wanted to interact with users, get people to come in to your store, get people to buy your product, get people to click on your website, all of those gains have happened in performance, which has been great. But what's beginning to happen is, as the watch time on various online video sites continues to grow, as more and more online video begins to be available in a non-linear fashion in television screens or recent, as Larry talked about Chromecast, that stuff, a bunch of the gaming devices, a bunch of other TV solutions, they're beginning to see a lot more watch time being expended either on your desktop or in your multiscreen devices or even in television. As that begins to happen, that advertising is more addressable, more directly attributable and provides more measurement capabilities. So we believe that, that's definitely a more superior opportunity for advertisers to be able to interact with their brand customers and actually know who's at the other end. So I think that trend is definitely in the right direction. And now, we're gearing up for it.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: So why don't I take the last question, which was the housekeeping item. Actually, this is pretty straightforward change, Ben. So in Q3, our Motorola and Google segments purchased and sold services to each other, and these transactions are reflected in our Google and Motorola segment revenues. The main thing analysts need to realize as they update their models this time is it that the total consolidated revenue will no longer necessarily, like in the quarters where there is transaction, to equal the some of the Google and Motorola segment revenues. So analysts who currently sum up our segment revenues and profits to derive consolidated estimates just need to model an elimination line for the intersegment revenue and profits in order to get their consolidated estimates. So that's simple as that. Thanks for the questions.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Carlos Kirjner with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Larry, I hope that when you come up with voice recognition it can deal with funny accents. Anyway, the perception by people outside the companies that Google spends a material amount of long-term R&D that will not generate revenue in the next 2 years or so. Larry, can you help us understand how you think about funding these projects and how much do they correspond versus your total R&D budget? And secondly, Patrick, you said in the past that CapEx is lumpy and we should expect fluctuations. But now, we have had 3 quarters of what looks like high CapEx versus recent past. Are the last 3 quarters the new normal?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Thanks, Carlos. I think we definitely are working on the accents, so I appreciate that. I think that -- on the long-term R&D question, I think we don't [indiscernible] detail. But I would say that in my struggle in general to get people to spend money on long-term R&D. In most companies, I think, even companies have significant R&D budgets, if you look at that, maybe 99% of it ends up being really incremental, which is relatively small improvements to, kind of, your existing businesses. And maybe 1% of that ends up being kind of doing long-term things like Android was when they got started. And so, I think -- I mean, I kind of view my job as the opposite thing is to get people to spend on the long-term R&D. I do think people have a perception that, that's material. I don't think that -- that's not been my experience since it's very hard to actually spend money on long-term things in any kind of meaningful way. And even the investments we have announced, on things like Calico while they're in absolute dollar numbers, probably significant amounts, they're not significant for Google. And I think you should actually be asking me to make more significant investments. I wish I knew how to do that, but I think it's actually very difficult to spend kind of meaningful amounts of money relative to global scale on things that are speculative.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Thank you, Larry. Carlo (sic) [Carlos] , on the issue of CapEx, just to reiterate the fact that the majority of the CapEx this quarter was spent on production equipment, so I think machines; data center construction, looking ahead; and building the capacity ahead of our needs to get the flexibility and real estate purchases. So we had a number of, kind of, really good opportunistic purchases in the portfolio we were targeting, and they kind of came online this quarter, so pretty pleased with that. I think that, overall, investors should see this as a very positive sign and as a positive signal. As I mentioned last quarter during my remarks, we continue to invest really for the long term. It's just the conversation we're having with Larry on the topic of R&D. And our infrastructure continues to be a key strategic area for investment for us. It's really important that when we see signals of -- or opportunities that where we need capacity, the worst thing for us would be to actually not have it in terms of machines and data center capacity. So the strategic value of having it for flexibility for our long-term positions are really important. That's what you see reflected in our investments right now. So thank you for your question, Carlo (sic) [Carlos] .

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ross Sandler with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Larry, just to follow up on Ben's question earlier, it seems like you guys have all the pieces in place with Android, with Maps, with Google Now, Wallet, credit card information in the Play store to kind of vertically integrate the experience from researched search to purchase in the local and transactional areas, kind of, the closing of the loop, if you will. So can you just elaborate on the overall strategy? And how does the recent cross-screen conversion estimates in Enhanced playing it out?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Well, thanks, Ross. We have our positions available if you want to help us out. I think we certainly agree with that. I think it's a pretty good description of me. We are working on many different pieces of your commercial experiences. I think, in general, we know that experience for users is not that seamless. There's lots of different pieces of technology and processes in order to make commerce happen and so on. So I think, yes, that's something we absolutely are looking on improving by closing the loop and so on. I think your question actually is a pretty good summary. I don't know that I can add much more.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Dan Salmon with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: My question was for Larry. Since you've come back into the CEO's role, one of the things we've noticed with Google is that your own advertising spending has moved up. And once upon a time, Google was a company that didn't need to advertise. And obviously, you're in a lot more businesses these days from where you started. But maybe, just philosophically, how do you view that for Google long term as you do launch into more secondary products other than Search? And then, just one quick follow-up with the Canadian government announcing this week that they'll look to pursue unbundling of TV subscriptions, would you ever consider taking Google Fiber to a market outside of the U.S.?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. Dan, thanks for the questions. I think we sell a lot of advertising, and we do a modest amount of advertising. I think we find that pretty useful, and we've gotten better at doing it. I think that it's good for our business. It's good for us to understand, kind of, the advertising perspective from an advertiser's point of view, given that's a big business for us. I'm going to let Nikesh elaborate a little bit on that. In Fiber, I think it's really just early days. We're just getting going on that.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. Dan, to follow up on the marketing question, I think we still encourage our product teams to go out there and get their products to be used by users [indiscernible] products because we believe that's the best form of marketing that they can have. But as our products get more and more popular, there are many parts of the world. We want to make sure there's awareness for those products and people to understand what the capabilities and features are. That's the only time we bring in marketing to kick in. And the other area we do a lot of marketing in is in trying to make sure that our advertisers understand the advertising opportunities, so they can actually spend money with us. So that's roughly how we think about marketing. But the primary focus is definitely on making sure we create great products that users use and a better [ph] products stand and get profit in doing this.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Right. That's very correct.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Gene Munster with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Question for Larry in terms of -- you talked about R&D spending and just the amount that you're going to be gauging that. Can you talk specifically about self-driving cars? I realize it's way down the road, but how real is this as a business? And then, separately, in terms of CPCs, how should we see this -- how should we see Enhanced Campaigns impacting CPCs for the next few quarters?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Okay. Good questions from Gene. Thank you. So I think -- I guess, on self-driving cars specifically, I think that for any big innovation I'm saying you overestimate short term and underestimate long term. That's probably a good summary for self-driving cars. I think we mentioned about this progress. We've driven large amounts of miles. We've changed the business from being something that wasn't going to happen at all to something that now is somewhat inevitable and people's feelings about it, which I think is tremendous progress. That said, it's still pretty early days in the product. I don't know exactly what I've been saying, but it's still ways from being a commercial product. You'll probably overestimate that in the short term, like I said, and underestimate that in the long term. Now for the second part of the question?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Why don't I jump in for a second on CPCs. Listen, we don't -- because you asked the question about what do we expect quarter -- or over the coming quarters? We don't really manage for quarterly CPC trends. We actually focus on the user and the advertiser ROI. So in general, right, we attribute CPC trends to a combination of those 5 factors that I talked about: FX; the 3 mix effects of mobile versus desktop; emerging markets versus developed markets; the channel mix between our sites and our network; then a number of product and policy changes. That's really the big driver. I think that we're really pleased. As Nikesh mentioned, Enhanced Campaigns is a great platform that enables us for the future. And as long as we actually have the format that delivers a great ROI, then Enhanced Campaigns will just accelerate this in the future, and that's what we're working on. So it's really the complex bustle, and it's important that not only we think about CPCs in the context of all the factors I talked about, but what's even more important is the dynamic of those CPCs and paid clicks other. That's really the magic that actually talks about our growth.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Brian Fitzgerald (sic) [Pitz] with Jefferies.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: It's Tim O'Shea for Brian Pitz. I know it's still early, but can you give us a broad sense for how you're feeling about the holiday shopping season? And do you have any sense if the updated Google Shopping or PLA program has given you better position to capitalize this holiday? And then, just quickly, can you give us a sense of what kind of traction you're seeing from the recent implementation of localized PLAs during the quarter?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. Just to say that we clearly do not -- as we -- as you all know, we don't give any sense of what's going on in the fourth quarter. We actually just are closing our third quarter, so we don't give forward guidance on any of it. I think maybe Nikesh can give a sense of where PLAs are going in general.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Patrick. Tim, I think the important part in PLA, as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, is that we are transitioning from giving users the answers in terms of links to dating them down to entities and PLAs, product listing ads. It's definitely a big step in that direction because we believe that's a great answer for the user and a good user experience in the long term, especially -- and more interesting on mobile devices. So from a long term user experience perspective, we believe that is the right direction, that is a good user experience to have. I'm not going to particularly comment how that is going to impact what happens in the next few weeks or the next few quarters.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ken Sena with Evercore.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: On Google Play, it's my understanding that much of the 30% that developers don't keep actually goes to carriers and OEMs. So I was just wondering if you can update us maybe on those negotiations and kind of when you see Google maybe receiving a greater portion of Play's economics? And then, maybe if you could update us, too, on your thoughts on Travel.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Okay. And Nikesh will take the Play part there.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. On Google Play, as you know, that Google Play has been something that our teams have worked really hard on in the last few years to make sure -- because that sort of fills out the Android ecosystem and is a key part of making the Android experience a great experience by having great content, great apps on the Google Play system. And in terms of economics, the economics, like you said rightfully, are shared between developers, carriers, OEMs and us. And our key with Google Play to make sure that there's a robust ecosystem. People like Android devices that provide some great functionality, and we believe anybody who brings value to that ecosystem should be -- should have economics with that ecosystem, whether it's a carrier or an OEM or a developer or us. We're not going to specifically talk about who keeps what part of the economics, but just to say that we're comfortable with the way the economics work out. And the more important part is it is helping drive the ecosystem in the right direction.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Also, Nikesh on Travel?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes, we -- on Travel, we continue to work on Travel. As you know, we have a great exciting product for Flight Search, and we have our IDA [ph] business and we're happy. We're happy with the business the way it is. We are working hard on making sure that the entity-level concepts that applies to product, it also applies to Travel as in terms of Flight Search.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Colin Sebastian with Robert Baird & Co.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: The first question is, I'm curious how you guys are thinking about the future of cookies in online advertising. Obviously, a lot of chatter about privacy issues and perhaps Google is working on ad [ph] idea in alternative. And then, secondly, I haven't heard a whole lot about Japan. Although we're seeing a pretty fairly rapid shift to Android in that market, I wonder if you could comment on the Google business in Japan and the pace of growth there.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Okay. So maybe, Nikesh, can you address the cookie question?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: I mean, from our perspective, we believe that technological enhancements can definitely improve user security, and we want to make sure that the web continues to remain economically viable in that transition. So we have a lot of confidence in this area, but it's very early right now to try and actually elaborate on them and talk about what's going to work, what's not going to work. But as I said, the primary motive is to make sure that we can keep enhancing technologically what's going on, but we want to make sure that we don't break the system and we'll make sure that things stay securely, economically viable. In terms of Japan, as I mentioned, Japan has been good for us this quarter. And as you rightly identified, we continue to say -- see robust growth in sort of the multiscreen space in that market. Clearly, it's an early adopter market as it relates to mobility and tablets and devices. So you can -- we're feeling very good about how the consumer behavior there is and how that translates with advertising.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Stephen Ju with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: An area -- different question on Google Fiber, if I may. It's now rolled out in a few regions around the country. Can you share with us some of your early learnings in terms of how consumer behavior change once the connection speeds step up materially in this new environment? And what kind of new services or products you think Google can roll out, or how your existing services can change for the better?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Thanks, Stephen. So I think, again, it's very early on Google Fiber. It's been announced in several places. I think we're early rolling out in Kansas City. I think, one of the things that's unique about the Google Fiber offering is that your television service is available right through the data connection. So one big change in having a high-speed data connection is actually the entire kind of television experience, cable TV-like experience comes straight to your data connection through your gigabit connection. And people, I think, have been pretty excited about that experience being a great experience for watching television, actually.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to John Blackledge with Cowen and Company.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could review the content strategy that YouTube and the willingness to invest in areas like live sports like the NFL and how the content strategy would -- will play in the evolution of YouTube over time.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And thanks, John, for the question. I think I'll give this one to Nikesh.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Well, as we've always said that YouTube is an ecosystem, which is a combination of great users, great advertisers and great content. And we talk to content providers all the time because we understand that users come to YouTube so that they can enjoy both user-generated content, other forms of content both short form and long form. So we're pretty comfortable that we're making great, sort of, progress. I mean, the number of hours that people watch YouTube continues to go up. The amount of videos uploaded to YouTube continues to go up. So as Larry mentioned, we're seeing a lot of YouTube users coming on mobile. So we believe our content strategy in YouTube is working. We are constantly talking to people about content all the time. And so, sure, we will talk to anybody who wants to talk about content. But for now, we're happy with where we are. In the end, our goal is to help make sure that our users have a great experience, they get to see the right content on their end, our advertisers are able to advertise on that platform.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Scott Devitt with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: A bigger picture question for Larry, and components of the question have been touched on in the call. But there has been a debate for some time about the Internet becoming more vertical and accelerated by the transition to mobile and that, that could serve as a headwind for Google's business, yet your core revenue growth has been remarkably stable for several quarters now, above 20%. Larry, you've talked about this broad topic in prior calls. But I was just wondering if you could give an updated view of the landscape as it relates to your efforts to go deeper into the transaction funnel to offset verticalization, as well as if you could share your perception of Google's competitive position in the multi-device world versus the legacy desktop, laptop world? And then, secondly, any timeline or thoughts that you could give on Project Loon in terms of it becoming a commercial offering?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: All right. Thanks, Scott, for the questions. I think -- so the first topic is a pretty complex topic. I think we're very well positioned in mobile. I've said this a far [ph] ago, we have the Android. I think we have tremendous services on Android, and we have obviously search and things that work across many different things. I'm tremendously excited about this. I think we have the potential to really improve people's experience as they move more into mobile and spend more time there and to make those experiences much more efficient and pleasurable and beautiful for those users, also as they do things with third parties. And one thing to keep in mind is we've done a lot of efforts around the APIs on Android, around working with top developers and around Google Play. There's a marketplace for those developers. And most things are evolving all the time, and we [indiscernible] users and help those developers. And so, we have a lot of ideas there and a lot of work going on. As I mentioned, I'm very, very excited about that. I think we're tremendously well positioned to tap [ph] in the world, move along and make users' experiences better and to improve our business and our developers' businesses. I think the -- I find I'm spending most of my time now on mobile, and not so much on the whole desktop world, which [ph] I think that's what people are going to generally do over time. I think, on Project Loon, again, it's really early for that. We announced it because we have to because people were seeing Loon and they're flying around and so on. But it's a small team that's very exciting. We've been thoroughly amazed by the positive reaction we've gotten across the world and from high-speed [ph] telcos and other people wanting to work with us, which is tremendous. We want to work with all of them. And I think I found something important than trying to improve overall Internet access, which is something that -- if you're one of the significant number of people in the rural area or a place that doesn't have great Internet access now, that's something that really matters to your quality of life. So we're excited about that.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Larry, I just was wondering, with advertisers having more choice of broad platforms to use for spending their digital ad dollars and, in particular, on mobile, I'm just wondering, do you see a big acceleration in dollars moving from offline to online? Do you see that pace accelerating over the next 2 years? And also, how will Google continue to differentiate itself here?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes, I guess I'll give that to Nikesh. I'll just say we've always seen a lot of choices in advertising. We've always competed well in that market. I think people are definitely getting more and more excited about moving dollars online. For us, I think, the measurability of it, strength from the tools that are available and technologies to do that, we're just seeing some amazing opportunity and I think people are more and more realizing them. Nikesh?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. To build on what Larry said, I think it's right that we are expecting more and more dollars to move towards this platform for a variety of reasons. One, there are more options for more players in the market, which are -- that means they're all working hard towards the same goal of convincing advertisers that this is the place where the users are and this is where advertisers need to be. Also, if you think about what's going on, as I said earlier in the context of YouTube, we are going to see more and more video coming onto the web and online mechanisms, which is more targetable and more addressable. In terms of our differentiation, if you look at what we've done over the last many years is we've [ph] actually worked in terms of trying to provide a comprehensive solution across all digital capability whether it's on Google, whether it's off Google, whether it's in our network, whether it's with us, whether it's with partners around the web, whether it's on mobile devices, whether it's on desktop devices, where there's some display ad, search ads or video ads, if you look at it, what we are trying to do is we're trying to make sure that when an advertiser wants to reach users, we can provide them with a kind of comprehensive solution that they can go ahead and advertise. And if you couple that with measurement, which is what sort of makes online so much more compelling that people who don't [ph] look at measurement, look at the analytics around it, so advertisers get a lot more information, they have a lot more options. And of course, in the end, we want to make sure that we focus on very high quality ads. So if you combine all of those things, we think we continue to be working towards providing the comprehensive solution. And we work really hard with all the players in the ecosystem whether it's publishers, agencies or other media property owners, so we feel good about this.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll go next to Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Couple of things. First, on the rest of world acceleration, could you let us know if there's any platforms like mobile or products like -- maybe YouTube that really kind of kicked in, in the quarter that really help drive that, maybe it was Google Play? And then, on Motorola, it's now getting close to a $1 billion run rate on annual losses, could you remind us of the synergies that you're seeing with that and why you're encouraged by that and maybe when that could start to turn the other way?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: So clearly, on international, not only is our kind of core strength [ph] business is performing very well, but also as you've seen other revenues, which includes the Play platform is actually doing very well internationally. So these 2 are the big contributors for that one. As we stand on Motorola, I mean, Larry mentioned it very well at the beginning of the call, right, it is still early days for us. I think that we have -- Dennis and the team have already made a huge transformation at Motorola. We have now great product quality, the Moto X, the first of the products that have come out, and it's actually been very well received great products. So the team is now really working on building out marketing and distribution, which is the kind of next phase of it. So that's the mindset that we put at Motorola. This is not a this quarter or next quarter but much more a more fundamental kind of optimistic and reset view of the company. So that's how we think of these issues. Thanks, Justin.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: And we'll take our final question from Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Just 2 things I wanted to ask about. First, just on Enhanced Campaigns, can you give us some sense of what it meant for overall spending in the quarter? And then, also, how do you get advertisers to use the location and time of day modifiers going forward? And then, just on the U.S. business, there was a decel there of about 500 basis points from last quarter. Patrick, you mentioned the networks shift there obviously. But was there anything else going on there?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: No. I mean, as a -- on your U.S. network, it really is, as you know, there are changes in policies. They basically affect dramatically more our network and because of our network, think of AFS, is really very heavy weighted to U.S. That's really was the main driver for that change. I'll let Nikesh take the front end of the question.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. In terms of Enhanced Campaigns, I'm not quite sure what do you mean by what it meant for overall spending in the quarter...

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Is it positive, I mean, incremental to revenue, do you think, in the quarter?

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Yes. We don't -- to be fair, on the Enhanced Campaigns, we're not actually trying to quantify the effect because we believe it's part of the overall experience and it's stepping in the right direction in terms of what we want to achieve. In terms of your question as it relates to location and time of day modifiers, I mean, these are requests from advertisers. But to give you an example, usually, when a car rental company advertises when somebody is in an airport, they are likely to get a higher click through it and higher conversion than if somebody is searching for car rentals when they're sitting at the desktop. So the location can be used as a great modifier in terms of advertising, in terms of getting better conversion. That's just one example. We have millions of examples like that where you can actually use location very effectively or time of day very effectively. The traditional example is when I'm hungry and you show me an ad, I'm more likely to click an ad which offers me restaurant choices or food choices than if I'm not hungry [indiscernible]. So there are different modifiers that allow us to create different advertising. People show up more at lunchtime, so there's a whole bunch of stuff that comes in when you start providing location and time of day modifiers. So that's how things get.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: I want to thank everyone for spending so much time with us, and I'll turn it over to Patrick.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Just before we close the call, I think we have great news to announce. I mean, all of you that have worked with us with the investor community group, you know that Willa Chalmers, who is part of our IR team, has been kind of missing in action for the last few weeks. I'm just incredibly proud to announce that Jacob Alan [ph] Chalmers is now in the world and has arrived a couple of days ago. The mom is doing incredibly well. So Willa is doing great, too. So just to let you know that she has not disappeared. She's doing great. The whole family is -- we're all ecstatic about it, and it's another great kind of Googler addition to the family. So that's why Willa disappeared for a few weeks. With that, I'll turn it back to Larry to close the call.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Thank you, all.

headline: Google Inc., Q3 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 17, 2013
componenttext: Cheers. Jamie, off to you. Thank you.

componenttext: Thank you. So that does conclude today's conference. We do appreciate your participation, and have a great day.
